result.execSummary:
On one or more charges, the deferred prosecution or sentencing agreement(s) on this case were fulfilled, and the charge(s) were dismissed.

The defendant Dwayne F. DeCora was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Child Abuse-Recklessly Cause Harm, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 948.03(3)(b).
  • 4th Degree Sexual Assault, a class A misdemeanor, Wisconsin Statutes 940.225(3m).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

records.addlTxt: DE and Atty TW Duffy came to Clerk of Court inquiring about hearing scheduled for today.  It seems the hearing was scheduled in error with Judge Yackel, cancelled but never rescheduled.  Clerk advised Atty Duffy to contact Judge Anderson's judicial assistant for scheduling.  Also contacted DA's office.

Removed hearing from calendar as it is a hearing that is Judge Anderson's not judge yackels. 
Informed DA's office as it was requested by there office. -ama
Motion hearing on September 25, 2019 at 02:15 pm.

DE's attorney motions and requests bond reduction from $10,000 to $5,000 due to financial hardship.  State objects to bond reduction.  DE's attorney states family ties to community and grandfather has put up the money as DE is unemployed.

Court reduces bond to $7,000, conditions shall continue.

Defendant Dwayne F. DeCora in court with Attorney Thomas W Duffy.  John Martin Yackel appeared for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant advised of rights/penalties, acknowledges receipt of complaint.  DE waives time limits for preliminary hearing.

John Yackel appeared for the State.  DE appeared via video means, in custody.  Court set $10,000 cash bond, with CONDITIONS: no contact with anyone under 18 years of age, absolute sobriety, no consumption or possession of alcoholic beverages.
